text: No hi everyone Anthony Fantana here
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for an album review Leonard Leonard
Leonard Leonard Cohen all the ideas
Leonard Cohen is a singer-songwriter who
like Bob Dylan or Tom Waits is a top
notch wordsmith know him
check out his early albums they're
loaded with really wordy stories
finger picked guitar and some really
faint accompaniment from strings
background vocalists and the occasional
organ electric guitar bass drum set the
instrumentation is good but what makes
Leonard Cohen's first four LPS
so attractive is his singing and it's
not like he's the greatest singer in the
world or anything especially on his
first LP where there are a lot of points
where his voice kind of sounds off pitch
what makes Leonard's singing so great is
that it feels so believable it feels so
real he really puts the idea of
songwriting up there with acting he has
the potential to come off really
soothing and hypnotic sometimes and
other times he can deliver his songs
with this really riveting conviction
that makes me hang on every one of his
words now on Leonard's albums he's had
his louder his Marc centric his bolder
moments but a great deal of the tracks
you're gonna run into in his discography
are quiet understated kind of laced with
this romantic melancholic theater called
Rama it's a style he's kept up until his
old age especially on this LP old ideas
which is kind of a reflection of
Leonard's aging style and you know his
aging self - at this point in his life
Leonard is almost 80
and his his age shows up most in his
voice which is really kind of settled
into this low-pitched gravelly smoky
sound that sometimes reminds me of Tom
Waits there's some tracks on here where
he's not really singing as much as he is
narrating in this really dust caked
whisper that's pretty gripping a lot of
his lyrics these days are still on point
- like with the opener going home where
I can't help but giggle a little every
time Leonard Cohen refers to himself as
a lazy bastard living in a soup it's
just this really kind of funny
self-aware and clever portrait of the
character that he plays when he creates
her performs his songs I like the breezy
background vocals and the the light hand
percussion the watery keyboards it's a
song that's very quiet but really
soulful to the song anyhow has a story
about kind of being mistreated or just
desiring someone who does not desire you
back and never did - and this comes out
in the lyrics like I know you never
loved me but could you love me anyway
or when Leonard kind of begs this person
to just hate him less it's just one
funny and desperate appeal after another
and there's kind of a sour comedy to it
and the vocals themselves feel kind of
sinful in this song and the music behind
them slowly paced this wandering blues
tune but I think the song crazy to love
you is where Leonard is at his best
just vocals and guitar and lyrically is
kind of struggling with the question of
whether or not he should chase after
this love that he desires
I can definitely pick out high points of
this album easily but I'm not into a lot
of songs here I'm not into this album
overall and it's mostly because of the
sound the production of these songs it's
an issue that I had with Leonard's last
studio LP of new tracks
dear Heather so many of the instruments
and the effects on this LP just sound so
plain and kind of corny I don't think
they
the drama or the sad emotions that these
tracks present the song wallow by has
this beat in this bassline that sounds
like it was programmed in a keyboard
that you could buy at Toys R Us and this
long different sides has this similar
cheap thin synthetic bass sound that I
don't like at all I kind of wonder in
the back of my head if that's a real
bass guitar on that song and if it is
how did they get it to sound so fake
on the song banjo the background singers
just kill me they do not fit in with the
atmosphere of the twangy banjo led blues
on that track at all and on the song
come healing the background singers get
pumped up even more for a kind of gospel
effect but how much they sing makes it
so so apparent that Leonard is not on
key a lot of the time because they're
trying to harmonize with him and it's
just not working I think he just would
have been better off singing that song
solo or just have the background singers
merely coloring the background lightly
like they were on other tracks and on
the song darkness that track just has
this really farty electric guitar that
sounds like it was plugged directly into
the soundboard to record it for that
track and it just sounds so bad and the
slide guitar and the piano on that track
too it's just so cheesy
this album does spare me some of the
headaches that I ran into on dear
Heather the background singers for the
most part stay in the background and
there are no saxophone solos but I just
cannot get down with the sound of this
LP at all there's some moments here
where it's bearable and I can really get
into the song but for the most part I'm
just too much of a stickler for the way
things sound to enjoy this LP and yeah I
know it's kind of silly and ridiculous
to complain about the sound of the
instruments on the Leonard Cohen album
that's not really why people go to
Leonard Cohen albums people come to
these albums for the lyrics and the
stories the personality and the voice I
get that and I think that's the saving
grace of this LP if that's why you come
to Cohen's albums then there's probably
no reason you wouldn't enjoy this on
some level that is the good side of this
album I just don't think that side is so
good that it fixes the things that I
don't enjoy because to me most of this
album just sounds plain or just horribly
horribly under-produced so I am just on
the fence with this LP kind of feeling a
strong four to a light five on it but
what do you guys think do you love it do
you hate it why and what should I review
